docs.abstract: An influential financier says investors should pay heed to growing risks and social tensions — a message resonating at the World Economic Forum.
docs.snippet: An influential financier says investors should pay heed to growing risks and social tensions — a message resonating at the World Economic Forum.
docs.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — As business and political leaders arrive in the Swiss Alps for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, a surprisingly alarming letter from an influential investor who studiously eschews attention has already emerged as a talking point.

headline.main: Chilling Davos: A Bleak Warning on Global Division and Debt
headline.print_headline: A Chilling Letter Has Davos Chattering

docs.abstract: The residents of Harlan County, Ky., depend heavily on federal assistance. That hasn’t deterred, and may explain, their swing to Republican voting.
docs.snippet: The residents of Harlan County, Ky., depend heavily on federal assistance. That hasn’t deterred, and may explain, their swing to Republican voting.
docs.lead_paragraph: HARLAN, Ky. — Gov. Matt Bevin skillfully worked the room at the old courthouse building here in Harlan, one more town-hall meeting in the long campaign toward next year’s election. He deplored the parlous state of a half-mile stretch of U.S. 421 and said $802,000 would be spent to rebuild it. He commiserated with the man who wanted to know how he should deal with the bears tearing through his trash bins, now that it’s forbidden to shoot them.

headline.main: Where Government Is a Dirty Word, but Its Checks Pay the Bills

docs.abstract: Big tech stocks including Microsoft have been leading the market higher, a rally that would have been hard to imagine at the end of 2018.
docs.snippet: Big tech stocks including Microsoft have been leading the market higher, a rally that would have been hard to imagine at the end of 2018.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: Microsoft Touches $1 Trillion Value, Signaling Big Tech’s Stock Market Comeback
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Hits $1 Trillion as Tech Stages Comeback

docs.abstract: A Tokyo court rejected an offer that the fallen Nissan chairman hire private security guards and surrender all of his passports.
docs.snippet: A Tokyo court rejected an offer that the fallen Nissan chairman hire private security guards and surrender all of his passports.
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For the second time in a week, a Japanese court has rejected a bail request by Carlos Ghosn, the former global auto chieftain who has spent more than two months in a Tokyo jail.

headline.main: Carlos Ghosn Is Denied Bail as Jail Stint Looks to Continue
headline.print_headline: Japanese Court Denies Ghosn Bail Again

docs.abstract: Dozens of senior policymakers who are trying to agree on rules for artificial intelligence gathered at M.I.T. There was even some consensus.
docs.snippet: Dozens of senior policymakers who are trying to agree on rules for artificial intelligence gathered at M.I.T. There was even some consensus.
docs.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Hal Abelson, a renowned computer scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was working the classroom, coffee cup in hand, pacing back and forth. The subject was artificial intelligence, and his students last week were mainly senior policymakers from countries in the 36-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline.main: How Do You Govern Machines That Can Learn? Policymakers Are Trying to Figure That Out
headline.print_headline: Forging A.I. Policy, When Pitfalls Abound

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

docs.abstract: A law passed last month allows the authorities to compel tech companies to build tools to bypass their products’ encryption. It has global implications.
docs.snippet: A law passed last month allows the authorities to compel tech companies to build tools to bypass their products’ encryption. It has global implications.
docs.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A new law in Australia gives law enforcement authorities the power to compel tech-industry giants like Apple to create tools that would circumvent the encryption built into their products.

headline.main: Did Australia Hurt Phone Security Around the World?
headline.print_headline: Did Australia Poke Hole in Your Phone’s Security?

docs.abstract: The search engine already cleansed its results, suggesting foreign companies can do little to get in the good graces of Beijing’s online regulators.
docs.snippet: The search engine already cleansed its results, suggesting foreign companies can do little to get in the good graces of Beijing’s online regulators.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Under China’s president, Xi Jinping, the last vestiges of the global internet have slowly disappeared from an online world that had already shut out Twitter, Google and Facebook.

headline.main: China Appears to Block Microsoft’s Bing as Censorship Intensifies
headline.print_headline: Despite Appeasing China’s Censors, Bing Gets Boot

byline.original: By Paul Mozur and Karen Weise

docs.abstract: Leaders from Japan, China, Germany and South Africa say that international rules are needed for tech, but there is no consensus on details.
docs.snippet: Leaders from Japan, China, Germany and South Africa say that international rules are needed for tech, but there is no consensus on details.
docs.lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Leaders of Japan, South Africa, China and Germany issued a series of calls on Wednesday for global oversight of the tech sector, in a clear signal of growing international interest in seizing greater regulatory supervision of an industry led by the United States.

headline.main: World Leaders at Davos Call for Global Rules on Tech
headline.print_headline: World Leaders at Davos Call for Global Oversight of Tech Industry

byline.original: By Keith Bradsher and Katrin Bennhold

docs.abstract: Nick Confessore, an investigative reporter who has written about social media and data privacy, has changed his tech habits after what he has learned.
docs.snippet: Nick Confessore, an investigative reporter who has written about social media and data privacy, has changed his tech habits after what he has learned.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Nick Confessore, an investigative reporter, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline.main: He Reported on Facebook. Now He Approaches It With Caution.
headline.print_headline: Worried About Privacy? Steer Clear of Facebook
